repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Closes #4763. When `!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT`, the module setup code sets `__path__` and `__file__` via calls to `importlib.find_loader`. That was deprecated in favor of `find_spec` in python 3.4. The deprecation warning is causing problems when running with `-Werror`. This PR
- uses the eqivalent of `package_path = [importlib.util.find_spec(module_name, package).origin.rsplit(os.sep, 1)[0]]`
- if `package` exists (`module_name` is a sub-package), prefix `'.'` to module_name

I tested this with `pypy3.8 runtests.py --no-cpp -vv`

It would be nice to backport this to the next 0.29 release if possible.

comment_data.body:
We normally try to make the Cython output as version independent as possible. Is there a way that this could be handled in C instead?

It looks like `module_name` is only used in the 3.4+ case, so you could just always do it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,11 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name
             if '.' in package_name:
                 parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
+                if sys.version_info > (3, 4):

comment_data.body: `>=`? I think the function was added in 3.4
`module_name` is used in both paths, see line 453 which remained unchanged. I could change the C code to prefix a '.' to the `PyUnicodeObject` in the 3.4+ code path, but that also feels wrong.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,11 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name
             if '.' in package_name:
                 parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
+                if sys.version_info > (3, 4):

comment_data.body: I think this'll be blocking ` build.cythonize_script_package` - these are blocked if it matches part of it, rather than matches all of it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,7 +1,6 @@
 # Specific bugs that only apply to pypy2
 
 build.cythonize_script

@@ -1,7 +1,6 @@
 # Specific bugs that only apply to pypy2
 
 build.cythonize_script

comment_data.body: I changed this to always prepend a '.' if the module is a subpackage, and added C code to trim the '.' off for pypy3 < 3.4
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,11 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name

+                if sys.version_info > (3, 4):

comment_data.body: This seems worth explaining in a code comment. It's not obvious at all why a module name would need prefixing with a dot. Is this triggering a relative import?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,10 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name
             if '.' in package_name:
                 parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
+                module_name = '.' + module_name

comment_data.body:
The C code calls the equivalent of `importlib.util.find_spec(module_name, parent_name)`. The documentation [for `find_spec`](https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/importlib.html#importlib.util.find_spec) mentions that the semantics of its arguments are the same as [for `imprt_module`](https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/importlib.html#importlib.import_module), which says 
> If the name is specified in relative terms, then the package argument must be set to the name of the package which is to act as the anchor for resolving the package name (e.g. `import_module('..mod', 'pkg.subpkg')` will import `pkg.mod`). 

This all can be simplified now that it uses `find_spec` to use the `full_module_name`, without a package at all.

Fixing.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,10 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name
             if '.' in package_name:
                 parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
+                module_name = '.' + module_name

comment_data.body:
`self.full_module_name` might already be an `EncodedString` (not sure). And there isn't really an advantage in adding a variable to this.
```suggestion
                        self.full_module_name).cname),
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3254,18 +3254,13 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # packages require __path__, so all we can do is try to figure
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
-            package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
-            if '.' in package_name:
-                parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
-            else:
-                parent_name = 'NULL'
+            module_name = self.full_module_name
             code.globalstate.use_utility_code(UtilityCode.load(
                 "SetPackagePathFromImportLib", "ImportExport.c"))
             code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg(
-                '__Pyx_SetPackagePathFromImportLib(%s, %s)' % (
-                    parent_name,
+                '__Pyx_SetPackagePathFromImportLib(%s)' % (
                     code.globalstate.get_py_string_const(
-                        EncodedString(env.module_name)).cname),
+                        EncodedString(module_name)).cname),

@@ -3254,18 +3254,13 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # packages require __path__, so all we can do is try to figure
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup

-            package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
-            if '.' in package_name:
-                parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
-            else:
-                parent_name = 'NULL'
+            module_name = self.full_module_name
             code.globalstate.use_utility_code(UtilityCode.load(
                 "SetPackagePathFromImportLib", "ImportExport.c"))
             code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg(
-                '__Pyx_SetPackagePathFromImportLib(%s, %s)' % (
-                    parent_name,
+                '__Pyx_SetPackagePathFromImportLib(%s)' % (
                     code.globalstate.get_py_string_const(
-                        EncodedString(env.module_name)).cname),

commit.message: move from deprecated find_loader to find_spec
simplify module_name to be the full module name

title: move from deprecated find_loader to find_spec
